content:
My official placeholder tweet. Due to the increasing radicalization and erratic behavior of @elonmusk I am mostly off Twitter. I'm spending a lot more time on Mastadon and in other communities. I'll keep my profile updated.

I'll still check in and post, but not nearly as much.
https://t.co/N3Gx3VHYfZ

The 14th CloudSLAW just went out and early 2000 are following along! I'm so excited I even went and sponsored @daringfireball this week because I really believe free security training ANYONE can follow may really make a difference. https://t.co/TkwASqkEoo

I’m honored to say my name is finally being used in a targeting phishing attack!

No. I’m not emailing you for your phone number or anything else from Gmail.

Really excited about my new side project- a free 15-30 minute cloud security lab delivered every week as a newsletter, blog, and YouTube video. 

https://t.co/2nNd5OwYaf

I’m not actively on Twitter anymore but you can hit me up on other platforms or email with questions!

If you want to get the best prices on our @BlackHatEvents trainings they go up again soon. This year we updated our cloud IR class to have teams attack and respond against each other in “Adversarial Cloud Incident Response”

https://t.co/Eqkgsvw6Ve
Anyone here have a contact at Microsoft/Xbox trust and safety? A friend (in security had his son’s Xbox account compromised (looks Russian in origin based on the emails used).

New blog post on IAM containment in AWS for compromised instance credentials. 

https://t.co/WiXfHzccic

Plus- don’t forget to sign up for the RSA Disaster Recovery Breakfast!

https://t.co/5hWxCWNtLd

Happy Friday! Want free CSPM for AWS? No limits on the number of accounts? No time limits? No forced up sell?

Yep. Done. Check it out-

https://t.co/HWtwS0DMkD

Migrated my Mastadon account to https://t.co/kM97k8yVGi. Looks like it went smooth and updated profile here so you can find me there. Chaos was a great starting home and donating as I move to an instance where I have more-direct involvement.
Just popping back into Twitter tk say hell yeah @apple! iCloud encryption for the win.
Just hoping in to say Mastadon now feels like 2008 Twitter… it’s nice. You should join us.
My god, it’s full of stars…
I guess this is one way to make sure Trump never gets back on Twitter.

I’m in San Francisco for an Irish dance competition for the kids and it’s at the Marriott Marquis. I am… very disorientated and may have just pitched some random dance judges on the benefits of cloud automation her at the bar.
https://t.co/W1fwQggS3K is now live.
Considering how many people around me are catching non-covid + sometimes covid… I’m back to masking a lot more after toning it down for a while.
I’m guessing Elon was also using 2FA and now he can’t get back in to fix it himself like he planned.

Wakanda Forever is a shining example of how a franchise can move forward after the loss of a cherished case member. Rise of Skywalker, while I don’t hate, is an example of how to fail in this endeavor.
Mastsdon is nice and some great stuff over there, but I’ll miss Twitter when it finally collapses. Maybe it will survive in a usable form,  JT not betting on it.
Building a filter for emails that contain “just moving this to the top of your inbox” to send them straight to spam.
When clearing out my DMs I realized that due to using a third party Twitter client I missed a ton of messages over the years. Apologies if you ever DM’d me and I didn’t respond.

About 20 years ago I signed up solo for this great group tour of New Zealand. 2 weeks and made some awesome friends, only some of which I was able to stay in touch with. Truly a special time, and the party on our last night was amazing yet bittersweet. 

That’s today on Twitter.
Verifying myself: I am rmogull on https://t.co/tGA8qexMCJ. 2CyFTCv-Bmkf-2iTcd-5fvyXocVpykZOEg6Q / https://t.co/oggtVfCIY9
Add your alternate social networks to your Twitter profile before you leave the platform. (If. You are, I’m still here to see what happens)
To give you a sense of how we view Kubernetes complexity, in internal product planning we call it “adding support for the 4th cloud”.
This years Halloween addition https://t.co/lHOia5lpwW

I wonder how many feathers I’m rufflingby adding this to an industry standard:

“Do not attempt to support multi-cloud unless your organization is sufficiently mature within at least a single cloud provider and has appropriate staffing and tooling to support additional providers.
Need to figure out why the audio is choppy but pretty pleased this came out so well. Was a rush job. https://t.co/5ZaK8je7pF

It’s been a crappy day, but writing a CFP submission for a co-presentation with @Beaker was a delight. Laughing my ass off. Hopefully we write content that can keep up with the description (and get accepted).

I realized yesterday that when people ask me about my career my response should be 

“I stepped through the sliding doors”.

I always have a plan. I’m also always open to scrapping it.

Yesterday I learned from my middle school daughter than some kids being blood capsules to school to fake their death in a school shooting. A classmates had a couple break and ruin her backpack. 

More kids are dead today before I could even post this.

I’m considering building my first PC in decades… largely for VR gaming. For those of you that know way more than me is that still the right path or are pre-builts a better deal right now? Also… I figure an RTX 3080 Ti but Intel vs. Ryzen?

I’m not predicting Twitter’s collapse one way or the other, but like any disaster planning it’s worth knowing options.

Where are people headed next if there’s a meltdown? Countersocial? Back to blogs (I wish)? Somewhere else?
I should add- Slack/Discord might also be options, although I prefer the async Twitter model since I’m always bouncing around.
Late start at the @Mandiant #mWISE  conference due to calls, but hopping into sessions since I’m not presenting until tomorrow. New event for me.
Heading out to DC tomorrow for @Mandiant MWise. I’ve giving an overloaded session on cloud native threat detection and response.
Note to self- don;’t get pissed off at Azure and assume something is broken when you manually revoked the permissions for the thing and just forgot about it.
He’ll dodge, but over $900M is a nice fat target for lawyers to find and garnish and seize absolutely everything he can possibly access. I won’t be surprised if he tries to flee the country.
People sometimes ask why I get so frustrated with Azure? How about “we only provide your public IP address via the metadata service if you use the right SKU for the IP” https://t.co/y4be8qsTlP
“ in the ‘crawl-walk-run’ paradigm this is more like going from ‘tummy time’ to ‘flying an airliner’.

I knock Azure a lot, but here is an example of when their documentation is great. Look at the chart that defines customer and Azure responsibilities for security. It’s clear and practical. https://t.co/AZ8Y1DHQoy

And thus I egotistically present my Grand Unified Theory of Cloud Governance. 

https://t.co/cBt5J7BLFV
I just heard about @kriggins. Devastating news.

On the upside, your business has to be in good shape to waste $85M and have it basically a rounding error. 

https://t.co/ltj4dcaR5G

Some people dream of making it big and buying a new car.

My dreams are more along the lines of “industrial 3D printer and maybe a water jet”

In response to @QuinnyPig I try to make AWS Permission Boundaries easier to understand, but I probably don’t. Tl;dr: if you want someone to admin some IAM in an account but not all the IAM, then you might need one: https://t.co/yC1kYWqUAH
I get to spend the weekend Cub Scout camping trip tethered to my Garmin satellite messenger in case… I’m sent places. Woo hoo!

Keep in mind if you are ever in a disaster:
1. Not everyone has resources to evacuate. If you stay, it takes resources from them. 
2. If you stay and need help it puts responders at risk.  
3. The sooner you move the more your options.

What do professional disaster responders do at a time like this?

Pack. Repack. Watch the weather. Get coverage at work. Some get pre-deployed to nearby safe zones and the track things to see where to roll out. 

Mostly planning and waiting to see where the need is.

I will absolutely inspect every single piece of my children’s candy…

… to make sure I get my share of the good stuff.
Alrighty- looks like if I deploy it will be as a refill mission so… seems the odds are in favor of me making our family fall break trip next week. #selfishdisasterresponder

I was sad after spending the weekend with the mountain rescue team and knowing I don’t get to do that anymore. 

And yet I’m sitting here paranoid I’ll be deployed in the next week because I’m on-call for the hurricane and thus screw up a family trip and work. 

I’m complicated.

Spent the weekend at the 75th Anniversary for the Rocky Mountain Rescue Group. I was on the team for 13 years.

Some team members going back to the 1950’s were there sharing stories. Absolutely incredible to hear that history first hand.

Also, mountain rescue is insane.

Anyone out there actually write Rego/OPA policies for operational security stuff? A coworker asked me after reading something and I know I’ve seen examples in research/blog posts but not sure how many security people actually use it.

Why is it that @verge seems convinced that only “Apple Loyalists”, “loyal Apple customers”, or “Apple Fans” buy Apple products? 

Is it possible…  just wait for it… normal consumers just like some Apple stuff and don’t buy things only out of brand loyalty?

Pro AWS Tip- AWS Security Hub will aggregate most other AWS security tool findings across regions and accounts… and then generate EventBridge events in that management account/region. This is rare behavior in AWS and provides a single point to siphon events.
@kmheintz @jeremiahg @taosecurity @Beaker @ryanaraine I always love it when actors are the real deal. Although then painful to watch Hollywood dumb down their skills.
The battery life on the #flipperzero is way better than I expected. So much to learn still to get the most out of this.

I’m getting very nervous I won’t be going to Disney on Fall break for the Halloween stuff with my family because I may be deployed. 

Yes, that’s selfish, but… there’s always a disaster to respond to. Just happens October is my month on rotation.
The only thing that causes as wide emotional swings as 3D printers are … children?

I did a bad thing and left out a major punchline- it isn’t just about ABAC, it’s about moving more access to Just in Time approvals, with attribute restrictions, and using out of band notifications/visibility. 

Guess I need more coffee

https://t.co/f0g8Wyhnwy
@KiwiDrmr That’s why we moved it to CLI and ChatOps- it’s faster and easier than managing them via most other options I’ve seen.

Weirdly- 20 years ago I wrote some of these concepts up for Gartner as something I called “Dynamic Trust”. It was WAY theoretical back then. But the cornerstones were Dynamic Authentication and Dynamic Authorization. I always thought we needed to split them better.

MFA isn’t only awesome, it’s absolutely critical. But it also isn’t always enough (as we’ve seen lately). I wrote up how I like to layer in security to authorizations. It’s related to ABAC (and sometimes is ABAC) but we have new options now.

https://t.co/f0g8Wyhnwy

New post on why you need to treat cloud misconfigurations like a threat/attack until you prove otherwise.

Well-known in cloud security circles, but not as much outside: https://t.co/lnrJgDLbRP

This morning Microsoft Word decided to just stop letting me click on any of the Mail Merge menu items. Almost totally derailed a class but it worked on my other computer. Not greyed out, no error messages, just… behaved like a static image.
@foodandwhining @GlennF Heard someone say that calling an iPhone a phone is like calling a Lexus a cup holder.

I love seeing all the cool 3D printed people like @diami03 and @mckeay make.

Meantime, I’m stuck printing yet another batch of fidget cubes so my son can keep his friends at school.

Promises were made,

Tomorrow- come check it out. This thing is pretty damn awesome. It’s so frictionless and simple I’m struggling to fill a 30 min session on it.

https://t.co/ldOZIdMrEH
Anyone have contacts in support/security at @YouTube? We have an older corporate channel with credential issues and support isn’t responding.

I really struggled with unjustified survivors guilt after 9/11. The horror those medics and firefighters and regular people experienced as they died. 

I applied for my fed position that October. Told myself I’d never be on the sidelines again. Selfish altruism. 

2/2

When I worked as a paramedic in Jersey City around 1994 I would navigate using the Twin Towers and the Empire State Building. My mentors told me of the time they responded to the parking lot bombing that almost brought the tower down.

1/2

Maybe we just need to stop calling iPhones “phones”.

Just took this waving my arm out my car window. https://t.co/gQ6usU2TA8

Great updates, but not dropping my Garmin InReach sat messenger or Epic 2 watch. The InReach is international and I can use for general text messaging, and the Epic 2 has a lot more fitness capabilities, including extensive on-board maps.

No dig on Apple, I’m just too extreme :)

@donkey They might, and probably will, eventually. But Garmin has a big ecosystem for all this stuff aside from what you put on your wrist. 

I’m happy to go all Apple once it meets my goals. But… isn’t like I don’t buy a new Apple Watch every couple years anyway.

@donkey I LOVE my Apple Watch. I’ve used both an Apple Watch and Garmin since.. there were Apple Watches and Garmins. Different tools for different jobs. Apple Watch is excellent for enthusiast. Just falls short for some of us for some activities

@donkey Built in global maps (offline). Dozens of sport modes- just yesterday I tracked a run, rock climbing (including difficulty and altitude) and bouldering. Ant+ sensor support. Better fitness metrics (readiness, time predictors, etc.). Way better battery (still). And more
Odds are she’s losing rentals because the management company hasn’t updated the site.

DFIR friends- anyone aware if Russia is targeting low-level human rights workers in Ukraine and screwing with their bank accounts? 

Because, reasons. I think we are at “happenstance” and not yet “coincidence or enemy action” but some of you will know better than me.

Microsoft Teams on Mac is so secure that when I log into one of my accounts it consistently decides to log me into a different account. Without fail.

I guess it *really* doesn’t want me to log into that tenant for my volunteer work. Microsoft working hard to keep me hard at work

3. Pt back in March. Oxy. Took a lot of time and narcan to get him breathing on his own, I had to bag him for a while and was about to intubate.

2/2

It’s Overdoes Awareness Week 

3 I remember:

1. First time I gave narcan in paramedic school. Pt. Had stopped breathing at chiropractor’s office. Woke up saying “I didn’t do anything”. Brother was the chiro and told of struggles.
2. Kid who got into poorly stored percocet

1/2

Okay- fixing my bad tweet.

On September 13th I’ll be showing off our new IAM tool- policy based just in time access via ChatOps (Slack/Teams). Nice, tight, 30 min overview and demo.

If you struggle with IAM complexity, this is a really great option.

https://t.co/ldOZIduiqz

Having a discussion with my daughter- trying to identify movies that are better than the books they are based on?

E.g. I thought Edge of Tomorrow was better. But struggle to think of many examples.

This list is excellent! Still can’t believe I didn’t think of LoTR. 

Hobbit on the other hand… I couldn’t even bring myself to watch the last movie.
@scriban2 Although I’d call Jurassic park a tossup. I like both for different reasons.
I know it’s lazy to just use Raspberry Pis for projects… but… sure gets the job done.

Yesterday I learned that MS VS Code works on Raspberry Pi! Friggen perfect for some of my side projects.

As much crap as I give Microsoft for their Azure security issues, they really do have some gems in the portfolio.

Our new IAM thing I’m excited about. Built for internal needs first, then converted to product. There will be a free tier once we finish with Early Access. Policy-based AWS JIT permissions via ChatOps with cool features like M of N and tag lockdowns: https://t.co/Ls90kGdM3y

New post on something I call the “AuthN/AuthZ Gap”. This is commonly known among IdM folks but I’ve found that a ton of security pros haven’t looked at it yet. Not a vuln, but bigger in cloud & something to know during control design and IR (containment).

https://t.co/M5UT3tGy5F

The feeble attempts by @twitter to now go after @dotMudge aren’t going to go well for them, and show a profound lack of leadership and judgment. 

He filed an SEC complaint, this isn’t a Medium post. This is not someone you want to face on the stand across from you.

Finally wrote up a post on moving to the “Attack Sequences” concept. Thanks to the many people who provided feedback, and quoted @fsmontenegro @s_crawford @abhaybhargav @nojonesuk @brysonbort 

https://t.co/dFLV2h9xDb
Just finished my semi-annual LinkedIn login. Trying to make it useful, but its just so spammy.

SciFi pet peeve-

I’m pretty sure if you are advanced enough to build directed energy weapons, you’d probably figure out how to integrate auto targeting and aim compensation… you know, like in all the video games. Or like the optical image stabilization in your phone.
Still hunting for 1-2 more teams to try early access for our new authorization control tool (AWS only for now). Think something like ConsoleMe but as an easy SaaS/PaaS deployment.

Hey @beaker… remember that time we had to bail on writing a hacking the cloud book because there just weren’t enough vectors/vulns/misconfigurations? 

Simpler days.

Looks like Warner/@hbomax are trying their hardest to alienate literally everyone, even kids. 

https://t.co/ueQXLwM3rh
If you think you might be interested DM or email me… Can do cool things like M of N approvals via Slack, IP or tag lockdowns (ABAC). Works with any SAML

Work tweet- we have a new thing for JIT IAM with all sorts of policies/approvals we are looking for some early access feedback on. 

There will be some OSS parts released, but right now interested in orgs on the commercial side first. AWS/Slack preferred, Teams also supported.

Anyone have an open source satellite imagery option they like? This is more real time than Google… to support disaster response operations (Team Rubicon stuff).

Or if you are a commercial provider and want to donate… :)

I’ve hit the point where I wear 2 watches most days at home. Garmin Epic 2 for health and fitness tracking and my Apple Watch for everything else. 

It’s a bit ridiculous, and I look forward to when the feature convergence is close enough for my wants (can’t really call it needs)

If someone ever did this to me I would have to jump on the nearest rocket and head to orbit to escape the…

Oh just watch it…

https://t.co/TLck2udjgq

Just read the funniest damn phrase about a paramedic deciding on a procedure…

“Do I let this patient die, or do I claim the kill for my own.”

Back in 2006 I was introduced to @gruber by @reppep. I’d been reading @daringfireball since nearly the start, and blantently stole some of John’s approaches to try and build my own site that was self supporting without selling out. 

Congrats on 20 years! And thanks for the help.
Found a couple Twitter unfollows in the last day. Weird, thought that wasn’t an issue anymore.
About to leave my first 1 star Lyft rating. I’m not sure cranking up the right wing extremist political radio is the best choice.
As I scan Twitter it’s clear I only saw like 10% of the people I wanted to over Black Hat and @defcon   Which is impressive considering I was there for 8-ish days.
Starting to pack up. Thanks @defcon for another great year. Hard to believe I’ve been gooning for this long. https://t.co/wMFXJNVnMU
I know I won’t see a fraction of the people I want to see @defcon but… glad to be here anyway.

Wasn’t sure I would be excited to be in Vegas for so long and look forward for defcon. 

Yep. Once I walked it it felt like home. https://t.co/RX89r2dK9a
My plans for an early night got pretty blown when I swung by the Black Hat speakers party for “just a few minutes”

Finished teaching our live fire cloud incident response class @BlackHatEvents with @__muscles   

Got a great response. We thinm we may do 4 days next year and add offense/red teaming, then put students against each other.

Just found out the giveaway at our @FireMon booth will be night vision binoculars.

Nice to see something different.
One nice thing about running our “Live Fire Cloud Incident Response” class is… less slides. We have hours blocked off for just detecting, analyzing, and responding to simulated attacks.

On the advice of a client a few months ago, I’m changing from discussion cloud attack “kill chains” to calling them “attack sequences”. The research I’ve done is more step my step without static phases like the Lockheed kill chain work, so it seems to fit better.

Finishing off the lab and code updates for the @BlackHatEvents class I’m teaching over the weekend with @__muscles. Not too late to change your course selection and join us :)

Right now I’m updating our cloud canaries lab.

Not to be “that guy again” but if you don’t want to get COVID at Black Hat/DEF CON take meals in your room and mask with an N95 everywhere. I’ve been to a few conferences lately and infection rates are very high, even among masked.  

I’ll be skipping most social this year.

Debugging is easier if you actually read the entire fracking error message.

That is all.
Note to self: getting upset that your test didn’t run < getting upset you spun up the containers and forgot to send the input
https://t.co/jB4h1rjpgm

I spent the beginning of this week at @fwdcloudsec and #reInforce. I’ve been using AWS since IAM was in beta.

I feel like a barely know what I’m doing on AWS. I feel like a pre-schooler on Azure after 6-ish yrs hands on.

Keep that in mind if you want to go multicloud.

Oh woah- congrats to @dmoren on being on @scalzi ’s blog!

https://t.co/mgm3fdHX09

I never really thought my career was going to be “old man is well paid for yelling at cloud”. 

I mean, it works, but really not what my high school guidance counselor expected.

Yep. Remember, all cloud security failures are IAM failures and all IAM failures are governance failures.

Encrypt everywhere? No. MFA everywhere? Hell yes. 

#reinfoce

Encrypt the Right Things, not everything. For AWS this is everything. For the rest of us, it isn’t. 

@jcfarris covered this well back in 2020 https://t.co/fErGUWfLJN

Disagree- don’t encrypt everything, encrypt everything your threat model says you should encrypt, and then choose an encryption option that mitigates that threat. Encrypt everything is great for AWS, but not the right strategy for AWS customers. #reinforce
“Security Guardians” not Security Champions. I see Space Force at work here. #reinfoce
Out at #reinforce. If I didn’t see you at fwd:cloudsec and you want to meet up, let me know.

I’ve now been to more sessions at @fwdcloudsec than any conference I’ve been to in years (including the COVID blip). Really amazing show. Live stream is free from the website and a lot more good content lined up today.

Scheduling an annual physical age < 50:

* Will I need to eat a late lunch?

Scheduling an annual physical age >= 50:

* Is my calendar clear for the next 3 days for my shingles vaccine
* …2 days for prep and colonoscopy?
* + 1-2 days recover before work travel?

I finished up Be Gone by @DennisF while on our cruise and it was the absolutely perfect summer crime thriller. He hit it out of the park. 

Be Gone https://t.co/WPmeHdOSMn
Headed to Boston next week for @fwdcloudsec and reinforce. Really short trip but let me know if you are there.
I have to right up something internal on ransomware, but thanks to @patrickwardle I keep writing “ransomwhere”.

Someone asked me why the maturity models start with “1” and not “0”. 

I said it’s like the Glasgow Coma Scale we use in emergency medicine. A dead body still scores a 3.

So you have that going for you, which is nice.
Half my day is writing automation code and the other half is working on a security operations maturity model. You can probably already make some assumptions on what the model will look like.

It’s even weirder when these are terms I’ve used for many years, and I just sort of assumed everyone knew what I meant, but clearly… not. Many different expectations and I never thought to even check.

I’ve been talking about Azure security concerns for a few years now. Most customers prefer not to even hear about it. They get legit angry when I mention.

Today’s tweet inspired by @QuinnyPig’s post. I’m really happy to see this getting attention.
https://t.co/psfkALPHqT

It’s always fun when I research a term to make sure I’m using it consistently with industry expectations… and everyone has a different one. “SecOps” and “Security Operations” are all over the place.

Which is nice, because I get to pick my own then.
One of the biggest obstacles to many companies adopting AWS is Amazon competing in their markets. Retail, healthcare, etc. I hear it constantly and it’s been a boon for Microsoft.
What Microsoft needs is a Trustworthy Cloud Initiative. They have the people, the knowledge, and the tools.

I’ve been having some VERY uncomfortable discussions with orgs about Azure security lately. 

Microsoft has some of the best security pros out there, but they aren’t engaged in the right parts of Azure. It’s clear its a culture/process issue.

Customer pressure is only answer.
Any favorite cloud attacks you’d like to see built into a simulator?

I include, and encourage others to include, auditors in your threat models. Why? 90 day password rotations for users with MFA is really low on an attacker-based model, but a high threat in an audit. Same for most encryption. The list goes on…
If you want to hear me rant about Azure and talk masks, I was on Security Weekly this week- https://t.co/cMP6htPZOR
My cat may not be trying to kill me, but he’s definitely targeting a hip or wrist.
